blocks.text: An API Gateway is a single entry point that sits between clients (users/apps) and backend services (microservices).
It receives all client requests, processes them, and then forwards them to the correct service.
**üîπ Simple definition**
An API Gateway is a server that manages, secures, and routes API requests from clients to backend services.

blocks.mediumHeading: Why do we need an API Gateway?

blocks.text: In modern applications:

list: Clients should not talk to each service directly

orderedList: Client must know many service URLs

blocks.text: üëâ API Gateway solves all these problems

blocks.mediumHeading: Core Functions of an API Gateway

blocks.text: The API Gateway receives requests from clients and routes them to the correct backend service.
It decides which microservice should handle the request based on URL, headers, or HTTP method.
This removes the need for clients to know multiple service addresses.
Authentication ensures that the user is genuine.
The API Gateway verifies identity using:
If authentication fails, the request is rejected immediately.
Authorization checks what a user is allowed to do.
Even if a user is authenticated, they may not have permission to access certain APIs.
The API Gateway enforces these access rules centrally.
Rate limiting controls how many requests a client can send in a given time.
This protects backend services from overload and prevents abuse like DDoS attacks.
Example: 100 requests per minute per user.
When multiple instances of a service exist, the API Gateway distributes traffic evenly.
This improves performance and ensures high availability.
If one instance fails, traffic is sent to another.

This helps maintain compatibility between clients and services.
The API Gateway stores frequently requested responses.
This reduces backend load and improves response speed.
Example: product details in an e-commerce app.

This helps developers monitor system health and debug problems easily.
The API Gateway protects APIs using:
It acts as a security shield in front of backend services.
The API Gateway supports multiple API versions (v1, v2).
This allows new features without breaking old clients.
It allows clients and services to use different protocols.
Example: Client uses HTTP while backend uses gRPC.

This prevents system-wide failure.
